verses.text: Now when David had grown old and was full of days, he made his son Solomon king over Israel.
verses.comment: David, near the end of his life, ensures a peaceful transition, choosing Solomon in alignment with God's promise (1 Chr 17:11-14), prefiguring Christ the true Son whose rule would bring lasting peace.

verses.text: Then he gathered together all the leaders of Israel, along with the priests and the Levites.
verses.comment: David assembles the elders and spiritual leaders, underlying the unity of civil and liturgical authority in guiding God's people.

verses.text: And the Levites were counted, thirty years old and upward; their number, by head and man, was thirty-eight thousand.
verses.comment: The age of thirty signals spiritual maturity for service, echoing the Levite requirement from the wilderness wanderings. Thirty-eight thousand is a notable expansion (cf. Num 4:48).

verses.text: Of these, twenty-four thousand were appointed to supervise the work of the house of the LORD, six thousand were officials and judges,
verses.comment: Distinct roles are established: service in the temple, and governance. Both the sacred and judicial spheres are integrated, prefiguring the fullness and richness of worship joined to right order.

verses.text: four thousand were gatekeepers, and four thousand praised the LORD with the instruments that David had made for praise.
verses.comment: Music and worship are paramount in Temple ministry. David’s orchestration of instruments elevates liturgical celebration, pointing toward heavenly worship (cf. Rev 5:8-14).

verses.text: David assigned them into divisions according to the sons of Levi: Gershon, Kohath, and Merari.
verses.comment: These three branches, established in the Law, reflect divinely instituted order, paralleling the enduring structure and continuity of the faith community.

verses.text: Of the Gershonites: Ladan and Shimei.
verses.comment: Gershon’s line continues, with Ladan (or Laadan) and Shimei as heads, showing family heritage as integral in ministry.

verses.text: The sons of Ladan: Jehiel the chief, Zetham, and Joel, three.
verses.comment: Orderly genealogy emphasizes hereditary leadership and continuity in ministerial duties.

verses.text: The sons of Shimei: Shelomoth, Haziel, and Haran, three; these were the heads of the fathers’ houses of Ladan.
verses.comment: Genealogies reinforce the sanctity of lineage, which in the New Testament is fulfilled in Christ's heritage (Matt 1:1-17).

verses.text: The sons of Shimei: Jahath, Zina, Jeush, and Beriah. These four were the sons of Shimei.
verses.comment: Some variation in names appears in genealogies, reflective of textual transmission over centuries.

verses.text: Jahath was the chief, and Zizah the second; but Jeush and Beriah did not have many sons, so they counted as a single father's house, together.
verses.comment: Genealogical merging when families were small displays practical adaptation in keeping the ministry sufficient and continuous.

verses.text: The sons of Kohath: Amram, Izhar, Hebron, and Uzziel, four.
verses.comment: The Kohathites held the highest sacred duties, from whom Moses and Aaron descended — profoundly connected to priesthood and revelation.

verses.text: The sons of Amram: Aaron and Moses. Aaron was set apart to sanctify the most holy things, he and his sons forever, to burn incense before the LORD, to minister to Him, and to bless in His name forever.
verses.comment: Aaron’s line alone offers incense and gives priestly blessing 'forever’— hinting at a perpetual priesthood, completed in Christ’s eternal high priesthood (Heb 7:23–27).

verses.text: But as for Moses the man of God, his sons were named among the tribe of Levi.
verses.comment: Moses’s descendants serve as Levites rather than priests, highlighting that the sanctity of priesthood was not hereditary for all, but for a designated line. In the New Covenant, Christ singularly fulfills both prophet and priest.

verses.text: The sons of Moses: Gershom and Eliezer.
verses.comment: Gershom and Eliezer are reminders of Moses’ family, but the focus returns quickly to the institution of ordained priesthood rather than mere biological descent.

verses.text: The sons of Gershom: Shebuel the chief.
verses.comment: Leadership is traced, even if only one prominent descendant is named—in keeping with careful preservation of order in ministry.

verses.text: The sons of Eliezer: Rehabiah the chief. Eliezer had no other sons, but the sons of Rehabiah were very numerous.
verses.comment: God’s blessing continues through Eliezer, emphasizing fruitfulness and recognized lineage within ministerial order.

verses.text: The sons of Izhar: Shelomith the chief.
verses.comment: This Shelomith leads the Izharite line, important in sanctuary service (cf. Num 4:29).

verses.text: The sons of Hebron: Jeriah the chief, Amariah the second, Jahaziel the third, and Jekameam the fourth.
verses.comment: Detailing sacred office succession ensures faithfulness in worship from generation to generation.

verses.text: The sons of Uzziel: Micah the chief, and Isshiah the second.
verses.comment: Each head is charged with specific sacred duties, exhibiting spiritual headship.

verses.text: The sons of Merari: Mahli and Mushi. The sons of Mahli: Eleazar and Kish.
verses.comment: The Merarite branch focused on the most practical duties of temple service, a humble calling with its own spiritual dignity.

verses.text: Eleazar died without sons, but only daughters. Their cousins, the sons of Kish, married them.
verses.comment: Marriage within the tribe kept inheritance and priestly service secure—a model of fidelity to tradition and family piety.

verses.text: The sons of Mushi: Mahli, Eder, and Jeremoth, three.
verses.comment: Genealogical record continues, underscoring the vital importance of rooting worship in tradition and remembrance.

verses.text: These were the sons of Levi by their fathers’ houses, the heads of families as they were recorded by name, counting each one twenty years old and upward, who worked in the service of the house of the LORD.
verses.comment: Unlike earlier age requirements, service now begins at age twenty, showing adaptation for the expanding ministry—a sign of living tradition coupled with ongoing authority.

verses.text: For David said, “The LORD, the God of Israel, has given rest to His people, and He dwells in Jerusalem forever.
verses.comment: The divine presence in Jerusalem foreshadows Christ as Immanuel—God with us — and God’s promise to dwell amidst His people always.

verses.text: So the Levites no longer need to carry the tabernacle or any of its utensils for its service.”
verses.comment: Transition to a permanent Temple marks a new stage: the old forms pointing to a higher, more perfect worship. This development hints at the transition from shadow to substance in Christ's fulfillment (cf. Heb 9:11).

verses.text: By the last words of David, the Levites were numbered from twenty years old and upward.
verses.comment: David’s authority effects this change, reflecting legitimate stewardship and guidance, motifs fulfilled in apostolic ministry.

verses.text: For their role was to assist the sons of Aaron in the service of the house of the LORD, in the courts and chambers, in the purification of all holy things, and the work of the service of the house of God.
verses.comment: The Levites aid the priests, highlighting interdependent orders and a particular focus on ritual purity—a reality fulfilled and superseded in the grace-filled sacraments established by Christ.

verses.text: They were to be responsible for the bread of the Presence, the fine flour for the grain offering, the unleavened wafers, what is baked in the pan, what is mixed, and for all measures of quantity and size.
verses.comment: Temple bread and offerings foreshadow the true Bread, Christ, and the continual worship God desires for His people.

verses.text: Morning by morning they stood to thank and praise the LORD, and likewise at evening.
verses.comment: Daily prayer is central. The Church would model daily cycles of prayer after this pattern, leading the faithful to unceasing praise.

verses.text: They were to offer all burnt offerings to the LORD on the Sabbaths, new moons, and appointed feasts, according to the number and manner as required, continually before the LORD.
verses.comment: Faithful observance of feasts foreshadows fulfillment of worship in Christ’s sacrifice and the ultimate eternal liturgy (cf. Rev 21:22-27).

verses.text: Thus they were to keep charge of the Tent of Meeting, the sanctuary, and to serve the sons of Aaron their brothers, in the service of the house of the LORD.
verses.comment: This division of sacred duties underscores the importance of apostolic succession, charity in mutual service, and a living tradition maintained in unity of worship.
